docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 11--Since the Korean invasion began, as much as $300,000,000 to $400,000,000 in "refugee capital" has flowed here from Europe. This has emphasized the growing role of this little democracy as the "Switzerland of the Western...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 11--Since the Korean invasion began, as much as $300,000,000 to $400,000,000 in "refugee capital" has flowed here from Europe. This has emphasized the growing role of this little democracy as the "Switzerland of the Western World."

headline.main: 'REFUGEE CAPITAL' REACHES URUGUAY; Money Arriving Since Korean War Emphasizes Her Role as 'Switzerland of the West'

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline.main: SHIPPING--MAILS; ALL HOURS GIVEN IN DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME

docs.snippet: ATLANTA, Sept. 12--A surprising triumph by Mrs. J. Albert Hayes of Philadelphia marked the second round of the Women's United States Golf Association's championship at the East Lake course today as she eliminated the defending titleholder Mrs. Mark...
docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Sept. 12--A surprising triumph by Mrs. J. Albert Hayes of Philadelphia marked the second round of the Women's United States Golf Association's championship at the East Lake course today as she eliminated the defending titleholder Mrs. Mark Porter of Westmont, N.J., 1 up, at the nineteenth hole.

headline.main: CHAMPION CHECKED IN ATLANTA ON 19TH; Mrs. Porter's Faulty Putting Leads to Victory for Mrs. Hayes in U.S. Tourney MISS KIRK WINS, 2 AND 1 Miss. Rawls Eliminates Mrs. Torgerson, 2 and 1--Miss Sigel, Miss Riley Gain

byline.original: By LINCOLN A. WERDEN Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 12--Communists theoretically demonstrating in sympathy with striking metal workers marched by the United States Embassy this afternoon yelling, "Peace, yes; war, no!" They also demanded that United States troops get out of...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 12--Communists theoretically demonstrating in sympathy with striking metal workers marched by the United States Embassy this afternoon yelling, "Peace, yes; war, no!" They also demanded that United States troops get out of Korea and that no Uruguayan troops be sent there.
docs.abstract: Uruguay Communists demonstrate against US; demand US troops withdraw

headline.main: MONTEVIDEAN REDS JEER U.S. EMBASSY; Uruguayans Stage a March to Back Strikers, but Mostly to Yell 'Peace, Yes; War, No!'

byline.original: By MILTON BRACKER Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: ATLANTA, Sept. 13 One of the most unusual matches in the history of the championship was called on account of darkness tonight in the United States Golf Association's women's title tourney at the East Lake course when the South American entry, Miss...
docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Sept. 13 One of the most unusual matches in the history of the championship was called on account of darkness tonight in the United States Golf Association's women's title tourney at the East Lake course when the South American entry, Miss Fay Crocker of Uruguay, and 24-yearold Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., had completed play at the twenty-fourth hole.

headline.main: Miss Riley Eliminated by Miss Rawls in U.S. Title Golf; FT. WORTH PLAYER LOSES AT ATLANTA Miss Rawls Stops Miss Riley, 1 Up, and Reaches National Links Quarter-Finals LONG BATTLE SUSPENDED Darkness Halts Miss Crocker and Miss Murray After 24 Holes Miss Kirby Gains Draws Largest Gallery Leads by 1 Up at Turn Bunkered on Her Third THE SUMMARIES

byline.original: By LINCOLN A. WERDEN Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Sept. 14--After turning back the stunning bid of the South American star, Miss Fay Crocker of Uruguay, when their fourth-round match was resumed this morning, Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., gained the semifinals of the Women's United....

headline.main: VERMONT GIRL WINS TWICE AT ATLANTA; Miss Murray Victor on 27th in Completion of Contest Against Fay Crocker HALTS MISS KIELTY, 1 UP Miss DeMoss, Miss Sigel and Miss Hanson Also Advance to U.S. Semi-Finals

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 14-- Uruguay today offered $2,000,000 to the United Nations Unified Command to be spent for supplies needed in Korea.
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 14-- Uruguay today offered $2,000,000 to the United Nations Unified Command to be spent for supplies needed in Korea.
docs.abstract: Uruguay offers $2 million to UN; repts inability to give med supplies; aid offered by Denmark, Pakistan, Philippines and IRO; Belgium creates 1,000-man corps; Sec Romulo hails Philippine Cong approval of bill to send troops

headline.main: URUGUAY OFFERS U.N. MEDICAL FUND; Venezuela to Give Supplies for Korea--Filipino Troops Held Part of Permanent Force

docs.snippet: Financial indicators suggest that the global defense commitments of the United States are accelerating economic readjustments abroad and are affecting the international movement of money. All pint to a movement of capital "away from the dollar."
docs.lead_paragraph: Financial indicators suggest that the global defense commitments of the United States are accelerating economic readjustments abroad and are affecting the international movement of money. All pint to a movement of capital "away from the dollar."

headline.main: WORLD'S CAPITAL IS LEAVING DOLLAR; Stocks of Gold in U. S., One Indicator, Reported Down $2,000,000,000 a Year STERLING GAINS STRENGTH refugee Money Flowing Into Uruguay--Canadian Bonds Enjoying Brisk Sale Boom in Canadian Securities Flight May Boomerang WORLD'S CAPITAL IS LEAPING DOLLAR

docs.snippet: TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 17--United Nations troops entered Seoul, the former capital of the South Korean Republic, in a twenty-mile advance from the beachhead established Friday in a massive amphibious movement behind enemy lines at Inchon, the South...
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 17--United Nations troops entered Seoul, the former capital of the South Korean Republic, in a twenty-mile advance from the beachhead established Friday in a massive amphibious movement behind enemy lines at Inchon, the South Korean radio said last night.
docs.abstract: reaction to Inchon landing, US regions

headline.main: SUPPLIES POUR IN; Force in North Said to Advance 20 Miles After Landing OTHER PUSH SPOTTY Column Near Waegwan, on the Road From Taegu to Seoul Forces Reported in Suburb Allied Air Strength Evident U.N. TROOPS SAID TO ENTER SEOUL Enemy Resisting Stubbornly Ships Move Into Harbor U.S. Advance Is Slowed Hills Changing Hands Enemy Resistance Stiffens
